physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It is set against a dark teal background. The decoration on this batik kain panjang is limited to only the left and bottom of the batik, with a small pair of stylised wings at the top right. The flower and plant form motifs feature intricate filler dotted patterns. There is a small signature at the top left of the batik kain panjang.
sgcool_label_text: The decoration on this teal kain panjang is limited to the sides of the batik.  Nonetheless, the artist used intricate filler motifs, such as squares, circles and stars within each main motif to enhance the overall design of the flowers and plant forms.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
